EED44B149CB64B5E89456A8697C23C39.description:
Construct and interpret a two-way table summarizing data
on two categorical variables collected from the same subjects. Use
relative frequencies calculated for rows or columns to describe
possible association between the two variables. For example, collect
data from students in your class on whether or not they have a
curfew on school nights and whether or not they have assigned
chores at home. Is there evidence that those who have a curfew also
tend to have chores?

AED7A5273A074064ACE8D0A731F24364.description:
Use the equation of a linear model to solve problems in the
context of bivariate measurement data, interpreting the slope and
intercept. For example, in a linear model for a biology experiment,
interpret a slope of 1.5 ùëêùëêùëêùëê
‚Ñéùëüùëü has meaning that an additional hour of
sunlight each day is associated with an additional 1.5 cm in mature
plant height.¬†

1E88989B7FE5447A97CA0DFF2566D176.description:
For scatter plots that suggest a linear association,
informally fit a straight line, and informally assess the model fit by
judging the closeness of the data points to the line.¬†

8B57D3F954E74C85941EF5443CAF4CDB.description:
Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate
measurement data to investigate patterns of association between two
quantities. Describe patterns such as clustering, outliers, positive or
negative association, linear association, and nonlinear association.¬†

EB5E73542B8C42FCA76738C186211084.description: Investigate patterns of association in bivariate data.

8560FC05E9E5479AB61400D1D3728E31.description:
Apply the formulas for the volume of cones, cylinders, and
spheres to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

DBC567FF2CA44112B91AA0F4876C9A0C.description:
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving volume of cylinders, cones,
and spheres.¬†

77620A2731C3436CACE4199F343646AA.description:
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find the distance
between two points in a coordinate system.¬†

DEA360AB22AF4BE19206A10D9ED1C794.description:
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side
lengths in right triangles in real-world and mathematical problems in
two- and three-dimensions.¬†

910148167F2342239F4F1CEC0717C277.description:
Explain a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem and a proof of
its converse.¬†

D4E049976D2541D9A88D9B74B62104D1.description: Explain and apply the Pythagorean Theorem.

81770D7F5CF04EA0B38AED08B1F89085.description:
Use informal arguments to establish facts about the angle
sum and exterior angle of triangles, about the angles created when
parallel lines are cut by a transversal, and the angle-angle criterion
for similarity of triangles. For example, arrange three copies of the
same triangle so that the sum of the three angles appears to form a
line, and give an argument in terms of transversals why this is so.

13DA480B15594E638DC77E146C6D0A64.description:
Explain that a two-dimensional figure is similar to another if
the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of rotations,
reflections, translations, and dilations; given two similar two-dimensional figures, describe a sequence that demonstrates the
similarity between them.¬†¬†

8FB314F76A964637B55FA153D259A13F.description:
Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations, and
reflections on two-dimensional figures using coordinates.

E9DB55362B1E4EA4AD6C0019F8F6649F.description:
Explain that a two-dimensional figure is congruent to another
if the second can be obtained from the first by a sequence of
rotations, reflections, and translations. Given two congruent figures,
describe a sequence of rigid transformations that proves the
congruence between them.

4DB2F6BFD95A4CAEBC4D3DA548C22AC1.description: Parallel lines are taken to parallel lines.¬†

FBDFBE9EA17A4EB2A3A262A32ABCC1E8.description: Angles are taken to angles of the same measure.

88A7A4D58B1244DC9913FD974369D208.description:
Lines are taken to lines, and line segments to line segments
of the same length.

E525A9BFB05245918B15C46C3F40DA9A.description:
Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections,
and translations:

B73F12ECE0924F35B35BF0E9E4823D3B.description:
Demonstrate congruence and similarity using physical models, patty paper or geometry
software.

7352EE111B51491EADCD369C4680ABEB.description:
Describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two
quantities by analyzing a graph. For example, identify where the
function is increasing or decreasing, and if it is linear or nonlinear.
Sketch a graph that shows the qualitative features of a function that
has been described verbally.¬†¬†

95D08E4E155F41EE846FF48FAB29EA74.description:
Construct a function to model a linear relationship between
two quantities. Determine the rate of change and initial value of the
function from a description of a relationship or from two (ùë•ùë•, ùë¶ùë¶) values,
including reading these from a table or from a graph. Interpret the
rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the
situation it models and in terms of its graph or a table of values.

006998A98281402E87A3C52B2F6C3C51.description: Use functions to model relationships between quantities.

71FE22DBEC534A3CB29AAA29D17335C9.description:
Interpret the equation ùë¶ùë¶ = ùëöùëöùëöùëö + ùëèùëè as defining a function
that assigns to each input value x the output value ùëöùëöùëöùëö + ùëèùëè; this is a
linear function whose graph is a straight line. Give examples of
functions that are not linear. For example, the function ùê¥ùê¥ = ùë†ùë†2 giving
the area of a square as a function of its side length is not linear
because its graph contains the points (1,1), (2,4) and (3,9), which
are not on a straight line.

CDC4583F1FB54CC6A9252E8E414BF409.description:
Compare properties of two functions each represented in a
different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by
verbal descriptions). For example, given a linear function represented
by a table of values and a linear function represented by an algebraic
expression, determine which function has the greater rate of change.¬†

959B36677C7C49FDBD34DD47A972DD5A.description:
Describe a function as a rule that assigns to each input
exactly one output and the graph of a function is the set of ordered
pairs consisting of an input and the corresponding output. Function
notation is not required in grade 8.

788A9B9BB40D45B2821AB4357881744D.description:
Solve real-world and mathematical problems leading to two
linear equations in two variables. For example, given
coordinates for two pairs of points, determine whether the
line through the first pair of points intersects the line through
the second pair.¬†

8FB9645827F1454389C2F3784082E9B4.description:
Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables
algebraically and estimate solutions by graphing the
equations. Solve simple (by inspection) cases. For example,
3ùë•ùë• + 2ùë¶ùë¶ = 5 and 3ùë•ùë• + 2ùë¶ùë¶ = 6 have no solution because 3ùë•ùë• +
2ùë¶ùë¶ cannot simultaneously be 5 and 6; ùë•ùë• ‚àí ùë¶ùë¶ = 11 and 2ùë•ùë• +
ùë¶ùë¶ = 19.

EC79ECD0ADF74EB58448DC10ECD3EBC1.description:
Describe how the solutions to a system of two linear
equations in two variables correspond to points of
intersection of their graphs, because points of intersection
satisfy both equations simultaneously.

A1F5D899F9294A05B1E5506769C30221.description: Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations.

DDBA8BBAE4E348569C4E67C18CDDF241.description:
Solve linear equations with rational number coefficients,
including equations whose solutions require expanding
expressions using the distributive property and collecting like
terms.

FE661667F7734A918AEF63D9EDB294E2.description:
Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one
solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions. Show
which of these possibilities is the case by successively
transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an
equivalent equation of the form ùë•ùë• = ùëéùëé, ùëéùëé = ùëéùëé, or ùëéùëé = ùëèùëè results
(where ùëéùëé and ùëèùëè are different numbers).

51A3811A24EC48268D62CF75E6FC1035.description: Solve linear equations in one variable.

21CB962B554249EEB147F4852130266D.description: Analyze and solve linear equations and pairs of simultaneous linear equations.

D8BBB21729CE459A8F87DF9323577AC2.description:
Derive from this principle the equation ùë¶ùë¶ = ùëöùëöùëöùëö + ùëèùëè for a line
intercepting the vertical axis at ùëèùëè.¬†¬†

16AA31837CEA4FF7BF39B7EA441079EB.description:
Derive from this principle the equation ùë¶ùë¶ = ùëöùëöùëöùëö for a line
through the origin.

679BB4DDA85E431BB4E866C1354473B3.description:
Use similar triangles to explain why the slope m is the same
between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line in the
coordinate plane.¬†

2FDD49E475DA418493E0F892E8296EDA.description:
Graph proportional relationships, interpreting the unit rate
as the slope of the graph. Compare two different proportional
relationships represented in different ways. For example, compare a
distance-time graph to a distance-time equation to determine which
of two moving objects has greater speed.¬†

AF3E9D5579534294B1F12FE130C52AE4.description:
Understand the connections between proportional relationships, lines, and linear
equations.¬†

61907B215F034629837171D9162335F1.description:
Perform operations with numbers expressed in scientific
notation, including problems where both decimal and scientific
notation are used. Use scientific notation and choose units of
convenient size for quantities. For example, use millimeters per year
for seafloor spreading. Interpret scientific notation that has been
generated by technology.¬†

3635D5C8F03E4704AF1596FBF47D5D13.description:
Use numbers expressed in the form of a single digit times
an integer power of 10 to estimate exceptionally large or small
quantities and to express how many times as much one is than
another. For example, estimate the population of the United States as
3 times 10 8 and the population of the world as 7 times 10 9, and
determine that the world population is more than 20 times larger.

686B8EA552504C22A775191DC3EC68EC.description:
Use square root and cube root symbols to represent
solutions to equations of the form x2 = p and x3 = p, where p is a
positive rational number. Students evaluate square roots of small
perfect squares and cube roots of small perfect cubes. Use bases 1
through 5 and 10 for cubes.

811FFBBD76A743838CDEAC63F30BEDCC.description:
Apply the properties of integer exponents to generate
equivalent numerical expressions. For example, 32 √ó 3‚àí5 = 3‚àí3 = 1
33 = 1
27 .

BDC0AD31B85F4AFF998A3E43A0CA7FA7.description: Work with radicals and integer exponents.

AF48A1E1CD2B4E96A9109032590BA0C7.description:
Use rational approximations of irrational numbers to
compare the size of irrational numbers, locate them approximately on
a number line diagram, and estimate the value of expressions. For
example, estimate the value of ‚àö2. By truncating the decimal
expansion of ‚àö2, show that ‚àö2 is between 1 and 2, then between 1.4
and 1.5, and explain how to continue - on to get better
approximations.¬†¬†

9275975364634C07AF351106D058980D.description:
Classify and explain numbers as rational or irrational. For
rational numbers show that the decimal expansion repeats eventually
and convert a decimal expansion which repeats eventually into a
rational number.¬†

3A84733B08CD4B88B8B2405C91D82690.description:
Work with numbers that are not rational, and approximate them by rational
numbers.
